annotated_problem.question: Three identical homogeneous balls are placed on a smooth horizontal surface, touching each other and are close enough to each other. A rope is wrapped around the spheres at the height of their centers, tying them together. A fourth identical sphere is placed on top of the three spheres. Find the tension $T$ in the rope. It is given that the weight of each sphere is $P$.
annotated_problem.solution:
In the text, $P$ represents the gravity on sphere $O$.

Since the spheres are completely identical, the string forms part of an equilateral triangle, so the tension $T$ along the direction $CG$ for sphere $C$ should equal the component of $N$ in that direction, i.e.,

$$
2T\cos{\frac{\pi}{6}} = N\cos\theta.
$$

From equation (1) and equation (2), we have

$$
T = {\frac{P}{3{\sqrt{3}}}}\cot\theta.
$$

Since $G$ is the center of the equilateral triangle $ABC$ formed by the centers of spheres $A$, $B$, and $C$ (Figure 1.11(c)), from geometric relationships, we know

$$
CG = \frac{2}{3}(2R)\cos{\frac{\pi}{6}} = \frac{2R}{\sqrt{3}},
$$

thus,

$$
\cos\theta = {\frac{CG}{CO}} = {\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}}, \quad \cot\theta = {\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}}.
$$

Substituting equation (4) into equation (3), we get

$$
T = {\frac{\sqrt{6}}{18}}P.
$$

theorems.name: Static Equilibrium Conditions
theorems.description: This principle states that for an object (or system) to be in static equilibrium, the sum of all forces and the sum of all torques (moments) acting on it must be zero. In the context of the sphere and rope system, it is used to write equations for translational and rotational equilibrium.
conditions: The body or system must be at rest or moving at constant velocity (i.e., no net acceleration).
Applied when analyzing forces and moments on rigid bodies.

theorems.name: Newton's First Law (Law of Inertia)
theorems.description: Newton's First Law states that an object will remain at rest or continue at constant velocity unless acted upon by a net external force. This forms the basis for assuming that in a static problem (where acceleration is zero) the net forces sum to zero.
conditions: Used when there is no net acceleration, as in static equilibrium problems.

theorems.name: Newton's Third Law (Action-Reaction Principle)
theorems.description: Newton's Third Law asserts that for every action force there is an equal and opposite reaction force. In the problem at hand, this principle is essential for understanding the interactions between the spheres and between each sphere and the rope, ensuring that the contact forces are balanced.
conditions: Applies to forces at the points where the spheres are in contact and where the rope exerts force on the spheres.

theorems.name: Uniform Tension in a Massless, Inextensible Rope
theorems.description: For a rope that is both massless and inextensible, the tension is the same at all points along its length. In this problem, this property allows one to equate the force transmitted along the rope around the spheres.
conditions: The rope must be assumed to have negligible mass and no elasticity.
Applies in idealized systems where changes in tension due to rope weight or stretch are ignored.
